results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
results.title: Leaked Documents Reveal Depth of U.S. Spy Efforts and Russia’s Military Struggles
results.abstract: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: The new documents appear to show that America’s understanding of Russian planning remains extensive and that the United States is able to warn Ukraine’s military about Moscow’s future operations.
media.copyright: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Television;Shannon, Molly
results.byline: By Dave Itzkoff
results.title: ‘S.N.L.’ Brings Donald Trump to the Last Supper for Easter Weekend
results.abstract: In an episode hosted by Molly Shannon, the former president, as played by James Austin Johnson, compared his recent indictment to the persecution of Jesus.

media.caption: James Austin Johnson as former President Donald J. Trump in the “S.N.L.” opening sketch.

results.adx_keywords: Delivery Services;Mobile Applications;Tips and Tipping;DoorDash (Mobile App);UberEats;Los Angeles (Calif)
results.byline: By Kellen Browning and Mark Abramson
results.title: $388 in Sushi. Just a $20 Tip: The Brutal Math of Uber Eats and DoorDash
results.abstract: Delivery drivers were hailed as pandemic heroes. But they say the rise of contactless delivery has made customers less inclined to tip generously and gig work is becoming an even harder way to make a living.

media.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.byline: By Frimet Goldberger
results.title: The Case for Staying Married to a Spouse You Cannot Stand
results.abstract: It’s worth exploring why, so often, our culture encourages us to run from the ambivalent space between “happy” and “irreconcilable differences.

results.title: How to Make Trump Go Away

results.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Daniel Berehulak
results.title: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
results.abstract: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.

results.byline: By Vimal Patel
results.title: At Stanford Law School, the Dean Takes a Stand for Free Speech. Will It Work?
results.abstract: After a student protest, Jenny S. Martinez wrote a much-praised memo defending academic freedom. But that protest shows how complicated protecting free speech can be.

media.caption: Tirien Steinbach, associate dean for diversity, equity and inclusion at Stanford Law School, was criticized for her actions during a student protest.
media.copyright: Brian L. Frank for The New York Times

results.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael Schwirtz and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
results.title: Leaked Documents Suggest Ukrainian Air Defense Is in Peril if Not Reinforced
results.abstract: A huge influx of munitions is needed to keep Russia’s air force from changing the course of the war, according to U.S. officials and newly leaked Pentagon documents.

media.caption: Russian police officers watching military aircraft fly over the Kremlin. Moscow could decide it is finally safe to unleash its prized fighter jets and bombers if Ukraine’s air defense systems are depleted.
media.copyright: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

results.byline: By Alan Blinder
results.title: At the Masters, Brooks Koepka Holds the Lead and Tiger Woods Withdraws
results.abstract: Woods exited the tournament during the third round that finished around noon on Sunday. Koepka held a two-stroke lead over Jon Rahm head into the final round.

media.caption: Tiger Woods after teeing off on the 16th hole on Saturday.

results.byline: By Simon Romero and Desiree Rios
results.title: New Mexico Is Losing a Form of Spanish Spoken Nowhere Else on Earth
results.abstract: A dialect from the state’s earliest Spanish-speaking settlers has endured for over 400 years in the state’s remote mountain villages. But its time may be running out.

media.caption: Visitors at the Sanctuary of Chimayó in the village of Chimayó, N.M.

results.title: A Great Credit Score, but She Can’t Get a Mortgage
results.abstract: Despite solid financial track records, many older Americans have a hard time refinancing because of their mortality risks and lower retirement incomes.

results.title: Jon Rahm Wins His First Masters
results.abstract: Rahm trailed Brooks Koepka by two strokes at the start of Sunday’s final round but surged as Koepka faltered to claim his second major tournament victory.

results.title: Banks Are Closing Customer Accounts, With Little Explanation
results.abstract: Increasing attention to suspicious-seeming transactions has led to some people suddenly losing access to their bank accounts. The reasons are often a mystery.

results.byline: By Austin Considine
results.title: How Brian Cox Felt About That Big Episode 3 Twist in ‘Succession’
results.abstract: It was a pivotal moment for this series, which orbits his character, Logan Roy, a conservative media mogul and political kingmaker. Major spoilers ahead.

results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
results.title: El Salvador Decimated Its Ruthless Gangs. But at What Cost?
results.abstract: In the year since El Salvador declared a state of emergency, the government has delivered a stunning blow to the gangs that were once the ultimate authority in much of the country.

media.caption: Soldiers on patrol on one of the main roads in Soyapango, El Salvador.

results.adx_keywords: Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Automobiles;Fuel Emissions (Transportation);Air Pollution;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Global Warming;Greenhouse Gas Emissions;United States Politics and Government;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Environmental Protection Agency
results.byline: By Coral Davenport
results.title: E.P.A. Is Said to Propose Rules Meant to Drive Up Electric Car Sales Tenfold
results.abstract: In what would be the nation’s most ambitious climate regulation, the proposal is designed to ensure that electric cars make up the majority of new U.S. auto sales by 2032.

media.caption: President Biden delivered a speech at a General Motors electric vehicle assembly plant in Detroit in 2021. The new rules would exceed his earlier goal that half the cars sold in the United States be all-electric by 2030.

results.adx_keywords: Layoffs and Job Reductions;Telecommuting;McDonald's Corporation
results.byline: By Sarah Kessler, Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
results.title: Work From the Office, Get Laid Off at Home
results.abstract: McDonald’s temporarily closed its corporate offices this week so it could lay off workers virtually. Was that a good idea?

results.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
results.title: Can We No Longer Believe Anything We See?
results.abstract: Human eyes — and even technology — often struggle to identify images created by artificial intelligence. Experts fear that may hasten an erosion of trust in media, in government and in society.

media.caption: This image of four people walking down a street, created by Andrés Guadamuz, looks like a standard snapshot.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Forster, Nora;Lydon, John;Sex Pistols (Music Group);Public Image Ltd;London (England)
results.byline: By Alex Williams
results.title: Nora Forster, 80, Who Married (and Stayed Married to) a Sex Pistol, Dies
results.abstract: A German publishing heiress and music promoter, she settled in London in time for the 1970s punk-rock explosion and became the muse to its baddest boy.

media.caption: Nora Forster with her husband of 44 years, John Lydon a.k.a. Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols, in an undated photo. “I fell in love with John because he surprised me,” she once said. “He had a sweet attitude.”
